Description: Glazed composition amuletic figure, rather crudely executed, in the form of a figure of the ram-headed god Khnum, standing on a rectangular base, with arms by sides, back-pillar tranversely pierced for suspension behind the arms above elbow level. The glaze is light brown with reddish patches.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Findspot: Found/Acquired: Tell Dafana, North-west Ptolemaic mound ?
Curator's comments: Probably one of the 4 "Khnum" among the "glazed pottery amulets of late work, probably late Ptolemaic", from the North-west mound, d by W.M.F. Petrie, Tanis ii, Nebesheh and Defenneh, p. 79 § 79.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1888 / Tanis. Part II. Nebesheh (Am) and Defenneh (Tahpanhes) (p. 79 § 79) (?)
Leclère and Spencer 2014 / Tell Dafana Reconsidered: The Archaeology of an Egyptian Frontier Town (p.40, p.45, p.62, p.180, pl.22)
Condition: fair (incomplete, repaired in two places near knee level, chipped at feet and base.)
